Palate: full carbonated. Finish: warm, well balanced alcohol. This was an excellent beer. I would highly recommend it. Great depth and balance.

Deep ruby color with a thick foamy biege head.  Dried fruit and roast grain nose.  Sweet beer with some molasses, brown sugar, chocolate and roasted grain.  Some grassy hops to add balance.  This is a malt dominated beer.  I dont prefer Scotch ales, but this is better than most.
Bottle shared by nolankowal. Aroma of brown sugar and a little maltiness. Dark brown with a thin head. Pretty tasty and very malty with a little hoppy bitterness to it.

Bottle, split with NachlamSie while listening to Explosions in the Sky. Very nice aromas of rich caramel, smoke, and a bit of earthiness and chocolate. The flavor is caramel, sweet rich malts, grain, smokiness, and a touch of dark fruit.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a dark brown red color with a medium beige head.  Aroma of honey,malt and fruit cocktail.  Taste is honey malt and barley with a slightly grainy/nutty aftertaste.  Slight hints of smoke as well.

Bottle from CaptainCougar I think.This had a lot more of a malt blast than I was expecting. I was waiting for that Peat flavor but really got a different brew altogether. This had more of a grain--chocolate taste but still was pretty tasty.

Bottle. Pours an amber-brown with a light tan head. Aroma is full of some big malt elements, a bit of honey, some chocolate and some peat. Flavor also has some big caramel malt elements to it along with some smoked peat and some light candied fruit...some nuttiness to it as well. A bit grainy, decent body with a malty/light smoke finish. The best thing Ive had from Highland thus far, and not a bad scotch ale.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2007 Pours near black with ruby hues with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of peat, rye, dark bread, licorice, and aromatic malt. Taste is sweet, bready, smokey with notes of dark malt, with a slightly alcohol note. Mouthfeel is full bodied with lush carbonation. Not bad, but not 95 percentile worthy.

22oz bottle via trade with CaptainCougar.  Aroma:  Bready malt with a medium sweetness.  Bakers chocolate, caramel, cream, dark fruits, light smoke, and a touch of piney hops.  Appearance:  Dark brown with a dark reddish highlight.  Light tan head was frothy, but didnt last long.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Bready/cakey maltiness with caramel and brown sugar.  Chocolate, plums, toasted nuts, smoke, and again a light pine hop into the finish.  Finishes sweet, but not cloying.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  A good beer.  Was  surprised a bit by the hoppiness, constrained as it was.  They sort of accentuate the other flavors.  Rich and flavorful, without being too heavy.

Bottle shared by nolankowal: Dark brown/reddish, with a light tan head. Aroma, caramel, roasted malts, some floral notes. Flavor, roasty, a light fruitiness, some chocolate, and was kinda nutty. Much better than I thought it would be.

22oz bottle acquired in trade with aracana (thanks!). Poured a dark, dark brown color with a very small sized off white head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, and lightly earthy. Tastes of bitter chocolate, lighter roast, and some caramel. Alcohol content well hidden.

Thanks to hopdog.  Pours a dark brown with some ruby red when held to the light with a small off white head that went away fairly quickly.  Aroma of dark fruits, toffee, caramel and vanilla.  Flavors of the same with some light roast, some coffee in the tail along with some bitter chocolate.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized light brown colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a semi-opaque typically carbonated dark red brown colored body and a fair lacing. The aroma was mild chocolate and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of roasted malt mild well hidden vinousness, dark malts and was mediumly hopped.  Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Any first impressions?
-A veil of foam rests atop the dark red.
-Beany maltiness and earthy caramel herald sweet simplicity.
-Its creamy caramel maltiness is definitely my favorite feature, helped by meditative carbonation.
-Sweet maltiness doesnt evolve into complexity, but manages to grab the attention of the malt lover.

What if you dig deeper?
-Some roastiness is found amongst the earthy soil.
-Supporting hop bitterness tickles the back end, but can easily be forgotten.
-Sweet maltiness develops light fruitiness, as raisins or dates.
-This is a very comfortable scotch ale which lacks the wit and intricacies of Corne de Brume or Alesmith Wee Heavy (for example), but which remains an enjoyable strong brew for malt heads.

Bottle; no date.

Bottle Pours a deep redish brown with a small off white head and spotty lacing.   Woody, earthy fairly sweet aroma.  Flavor was similar woody carmel wioth some grassy bitterness.  Very low on the hops,  and a decent full palate.  A nice example of a style that I like.  Thanks Jordan

Bottle: Dark brown mahogany color, light tan head and lacing. Nose of light fig and sweet olive crusted rye bread and kalamata. Light cheese. The flavor is sweet and rye with a nice sweet pumpkin seed, caramel and roast note. Moderate alcohol and sweet nice melanoidins. Finishes caramelly and chewy with lots of umami. Good!

22oz bomber from NachlamSie, no date.  Pours a deep red with some brown highlights with a small beige head.  Aroma of unsweet caramel malts, some bitter chocolate malts, a little roasty malts and light charred wood--though not really smoky.  If I picked up on  any hops, they were more  earthy.   Flavor is much more sweet and raisiny, but that doesnt mean the roasty bitterness has gone.  There is also some sweet toffee and a faint sour acidity.  Finishes lightly chalky and roasty grainy.  Alcohol is covered well, but still a little warming.  Full bodied, very creamy with light carbonation.  Very good beer.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 22 oz bottle (thanks to acertain!) into a Snifter style glass.  Pours a deep ruby red brown color with a fairly foamy tanned head...the brew looks heavily carbonated.  The aroma is a blast of huge carmalized and roasted malts with hints of chocolate and bittered hops thrown in the mix.  A tiny bit of alcohol is hidden in the nose very well as well.  Just a tiny hint to let you know its there - but nothing overpowering.  When this one hits the toungue at first a lovely and sweet carmalized malt swoops over the palate, which slowly (with huge, dense bubbles dancing over the tongue) progresses into a roasted grain and hopped game, the two with equal balance, but both trying to take over.  In there somewhere as the sip goes into the throat is a well done chocolate taste that gives in to an also well done alcohol singe that will leave the palate with a highly complex aftertaste.  This one has a thick and chewy body throughout the whole thing.  Im really beginning to enjoy Scotch style ales more and more - especially when theyre done as well as this!  Thanks again to acertain...hopefully I can find another one of these soon!

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 Mmmmm..... quite nice!!  Chocolate sweet malts to the nose, with some very well-integrated roasts.  The pour is almost opaque black, but not quite.  A thin ring tan head follows the brew down the glass (1/8-inch)... sudsy webbed lace is left behind.  The flavor is a sweetly roasted chocolate, with coffee-esque hues.  The finish is hopped nicely, lending a tiny bite to the sweet malts and providing a very satiating palate.  Mmmm, honestly begs for another.  A truly great beer!  An instant classic, in my book.
(660ml bottle) Scotch. Hi-ABV nose. Burn with a smooth cocoa resistance and a pale Carolina malt. Good.

Good sized, light brown head of very, very fine and dense bubbles.  Settles slowly and leaves a thick blanket of foam remaining.  Rich malty aroma.  Lots of toffee and caramel.  Lots of roastyness and a hint of smoke.  Color is a dark mahagony brown.  Sweet malty flavor with a solid roasty and peaty background.  Hint of smoke again.  Thick and chewy and very smooth.  Hides its alcohol very well.  Flavor is a little weak though.  Finishes pretty clean.  A pretty good scotch ale.

Bottle thanks to ross.  Dark mahogany pour with a small tan head.  Brown sugar aroma, peat smoke, slight spicy hop background.  Caramel flavor up front, roasty/smoky body, notable hop finish, and a little spicy.  Creamy medium body, dry finish.

Bottle scored most likely from the Tom and Larry show.  Deep brown colored with nice ruby highlights.  Smaller fast fading head, some lacing.  Big roasted grain aroma, lots of caramel.  Full bodied.  Exceptionally malty, light background of hops.  Tasty.

22oz - Aroma is bitter toffee and carmel with a  touch of toasted chocolate malt.  Pours dark brown with a small head and decent lacing.  Flavor is intense toasted barley, chocolate, toffee and carmel.  Palate is chewy and creamy.  A very nice Scotch ale.

Thanks Ross! Pours a deep russet brown with a loose tan head. Aroma is huge caramel, chocolate, cookie maltiness. Sweet and alcoholic. The body is med.-thick. with low CO2. Resinous maltiness, lots of kettle caramalization. Some cocoa. Lite chocolate. Lite alcohol. Overall, very balanced. Nicely bitter sweet finish.  

Really great beer that doesnt seem to know what it is. Not nearly thick enough for a Wee Heavy but not hoppy enough for an American Strong Ale.

Bomber courtesy of Ross, thank you! Scotch ales are amongst my least understood style of beer. Often I get confused between a "scotch ale" and a "Scottish" ale. My understanding of the style "scotch ale" is a malt oriented beer with strong leaning towards scotches. Since hops never did flourish in Scotland, but grains did (and still do), Scottish brewers have been aiming at pefecting heavily malted, sweet, and smokey beers using ingredients that are readily available to them. This one is brewed in North Carolina, which is thousands of miles from Scotland, but whats clear is that Highland has done their homework. This beer is the deepest amber known to man. It pours almost still, with just a modest ring of beige foam. This beer transports you to a cloudy day in Scotland almost instantly. Youre sitting on your porch.You can smell the chimney smoke of your neighbours home, the single malt scotch that perhaps your father is enjoying while sitting in his chair inside. The fresh peat and wet wood of the nearby forest, where you used to play as a child. Your mother is just finishing cooking up dinner, and while youre not sure what shes made, you can smell the burnt sugars and figs of whatever it is. You close your eyes, your mouth waters, and you think of all these aromas you are smelling. Could there be something that tastes exactly how it smells..........suddenly your not in Scotland anymore.......but youve got a bottle of Highlands Tasgall ale in front of you, and almost instantly youre not surprised.

Bottle courtesy of Ross. Bottled at the brewery. Toasty malt aroma, with some plum notes, but not in your face. Pours cola brown with a foamy diminishing head. Slick but fizzy mouthfeel. Flavor of dark fruits , molasses, spice, and a hint of peat. Could use a little sweetness. Moderately bitter finish twith some Semi dry  red wine notes.  This has a pleasant lingering spiciness. An interesting take on a scotch ale, and Highlands best beer  IMO. Although I need to rerate the other beers with non-contracted samples.

A very dark brown Scotch Ale, with a light tan head.  Rich and creamy - great, full mouthfeel, with a rich, bitter coffee/chocolate finish.  Not too sweet at all.  It is very nutty and full-bodied.  Very good.

Thanks to ross for this bottle - deep reddish-purple pour, with well-sustained, off-white head - nice smoke and peat presence, with hints of plum, chocolate and caramel, along with a fig-and-toffee, almost english barleywine aroma - the flavor is equal amounts dry and malty - dry cocoa and smokey qualities couple with medium caramel and chocolate malt swetness - light peat flavors - some gentle barleywine character from the aroma comes late to the flavor - slight alcohol warmth - a unique and tasty scotch ale - someone please send me some more!

650ml bottle. My first Scotch Ale. Pours dark red with a thin tan head. Chocolate maltiness, toffee, and a bit of scotch. Somewhat fruity taste, mostly chocolate malt. Bitter bready finish. Not that different from strong stouts.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of ross.  Pours a deep brown with a thin tan head.  Plenty of dark malts in the aroma along with some vanilla extract, chocolate and a sour nuttiness.  Harshly carbonated upfront, yet still goes down smooth.  Lots of sweet, chocolatey malts to start.  Caramel, plums, raisins and smokiness in the middle.  A nicely bitter hoppy finish with a mix of biscuits and dark coffee.  Delicious.

Bottle. Small tan fizzy head that mostly diminished, sparse lacing, mostly opaque with a little light coming through to see that there was some carbonation, and a dark brown hue with a little orange peeking through. Malty, chocolate and a whiff of scotch. Nicely done. Sweet, malty, chcolate, vinuous but not overly done. Nice flavor. Mouthfeel was tingly. A nicely made scotch ale and worth seeking out if one enjoys this style.

Very dark brown pour with a nice brown/tan head.   Sweet malty aroma with some chocolate, bourbon and dried fruit.  Active carbonation but smooth tasting.  Very sweet initially.  A little bit of alcohol creeps into the middle.  Lots going on in the finish which is moderately bitter and sticky.  Chocolate, plum, raisin just a lot of fruit maybe some citrus hops... some smoke and peat.  Nice!

Bottle, from trade with ross. Good nose, sweet. Caramel. milk, nutty, hint of scotch & smoke. Little of the ABV shows itself. Hazy orangy brown color, small head (I poured kind of slow) that faded to a ring. Ok lace. Sweet bitter flavor, like aroma, but a fruitiness comes out I didnt find in the aroma. Raisin, plum. kicks in. Has a bite about it. Thick body, creamy oily mouthfeel, sweet bitter finish. Very tasty. Truly a winner from Highland. Thanks ross!
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle... Clear, dark, deep ruby ale with a small, frothy, khaki head. Good retention. Malty, earthy aroma with notes of caramel and light smoke. The well-balanced flavor is very grainy with plenty of caramel, medium sherry and spent mash. Medium bitterness... enough hops to knock down the sweetness without totally eclipsing the rich, malty character. Full-bodied and sticky with marginal carbonation. Lengthy, malty, then bitter finish. Probably too well-bittered to be true to style, but delicious. Reminds me of Three Floyds Robert the Bruce Scottish Ale. Thanks go out to CaptainCougar for sending the bottle!
roasty, sweet, sugary, caramel, chocolate aroma.  very dark brown, almost black, color with a orange-tan head.  flavor is lightly smokey with chocolate and a bit of hops.  tastey stuff.

22 oz bottle obtained in a trade with aracauna months ago.  clear mahogony topped with a light tan head.  big brown sugar nose with light toffee and a touch of sourness, which dispated once the beer warmed up a bit.  light rasins/grape and passionfruit in the mix as well.  lots of fruity flavors here with undertones of chocolate, char and some chak-like feel.  alchol is nowhere to be found here.  really doenst come across as a scotch ale at all-i would called it a spiced ale.

Courtesy of NachlamSie. Dark multi brown. Smaller light khaki colored cap. Flavor and aroma of roasty malt, cocoa powder, earth, very light smoke, and resinous hops. Full/medium, balanced body. Very nice brew.

Bottle thanks to Willblake at HW open house. Dark brown with red highlights and a small tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, caramel malts and just a bit of smoke. Flavor is again very chocolatey, with some dark dried fruits, caramel and again just a hint of smokiness.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- my bottle courtesy of ross. Pours a murky dark ruby with a good size tan head. Slightly mild aroma of caramel malt, smoke, chocolate and hops. Flavour is nice and malty with some smoke, hops, chocolate, dark fruit and alcohol. Medium bodied. This is definitely up there with some of the best Scotch Ales Ive had -- great stuff!

Big thanks to Beerdrenched for sharing this brew.  Pours dark ruby / brown with a fairly small tan head.  Aroma has brown sugar and dark fruits (passion fruit?) with some tartness.  Med / full body beer with light soft carbonation.  Taste has chalky chocolate with dark fruits (figs?) - there is a light roastiness as well.  Finish starts chalky adn sour.  Further down the sourness turnes to spiciness.  Chocolate gets richer further down as well, pretty creamy.  A very nice beer, but not too much resemblence to a scotch ale in my opinion.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, tupalev & jerc - courtesy of blankboy. Deep garnet with a small tan head. Aroma is a bit stale, but pleasant - lots of malt, a bit of smoke and some tartness in the finish. Flavour is very nice - malt & chocolate, a bit earthy, and a hint of spice & smoke in the finish. Very nice!

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2008 Another re-rate courtesy of Jon - I came in a 4.0 this time, 3.8 last.  A big peaty, smoky Scotch Ale, fantastic again!

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry, GregClow, Blankboy, and Jerc, Blankboys bottle.  Nice deep dark brown, small tan head.  Decent malt, hint of smoke and alcohol in mild aroma.  Wow, doesnt prepare you for the incredible taste:  deep, rich sweet chocolate malts which compliment the alcohol.  Toast-like finish with some nice bitterness.  There are a ton of flavours in this rich hearty brew.  It started off average and finished as one of the best Scotch Ales I have ever had, well done Highland.

Bottle. Roasted grain - granola, honey, a bit spice. Cloudy brown, low off-white head.
Vineous raisin base, chocolate and coffee. Medium body, mellow sparkly body. Nice spicy beer.

Dark brown with mahogany edges. Huge beige head. Up front all kinds of malt. Arom consists of smoky sweet malt, chocolate, fig, prune, faint hop detectable in background. Flavor all over the place. Smoky, caramel, roasted grain, prunes, dry oats, very faint alcohol. Mouthfeel is borderline 5 but appears a tad thin at times. Hard to bump individual scores up but, without question the best scotch ale I have ever had.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 2008-07-04. Very dark brown, small khaki head. (3+) Sweetish aroma, touch of peat, malt. (7+) Sweet malt, mild sugars, touch of peat again. (7+) Smooth average to medium palate. Decent well executed Scotch ale, the peat while restrained is just enough to diminish my enjoyment of it. Still quite good. 8/3+/7/3/15-16 Bottle shared by Jon Walker
June 2006. Dark brown body, small tan head. (3+) Malty, earthy aroma, very light anise notes. Similar flavour with lots of earthy malt, caramel and very light hints of licorice. Medium palate. (3+) Quite nice. A very nice Scotch ale. 7/4/8/4/16 - 3.9

Bottle (650ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc and tupalev - blankboys bottle.  Poured deep clear ruby with a decent creamy tan head.  Aroma - malty! - lightly roast malt, lactose, very mild slightly funky hops, chocolate, oats and a hint of fresh peat.  Lord this is tasty - huge malt character, almost burnt, oats, some alcohol, more bitter hops than the nose indicated, stewed prunes and chocolate on warming, a lovely, long complex malty finish.  Thick creamy body, left me wanting more:  terrific scotch ale.
Caramel in the nose.  Pours a dark brown.  Sweet, a little sour, some vanilla in the flavor.

A 22oz bomber Ive had for over 6 months. Finally cracked it open and man did I enjoy. Pours a dark brown with a nice dark tan head. An aroma of malt, chocolate and light alcohol. A good flavor of sweet malt and light alcohol. An excellent thick mouth feel. I drank this beer at about 55 degress it was excellent.

Bottle.  Pours black with dark brown around the edges, and a moderate tan head.  Aroma is of semi-sweet chocolate, dark fruit, and a hint of nuttiness.  Flavor is sweet but not overly so, with dark fruits, semisweet chocolate, a bit of caramel, a hint of breadiness, and numerous other flavors that are hard to isolate.  Finishes dry, a bit astringent, and pleasantly fruity.  Very well done; complex and excellently blended.

Good brown color with an oddly bleach white head. Tons of lacing. Slightly smokey with caramelly and chocolate malt smell to it. Hint of bready malt. Sweet dark fruity start. Roasted Starbucks coffee taste follows. Sweet caramel malt blesses the mouth as this beer finishes strong and dry with mostly the caramel taste coming back. The alcohol is extremely well hidden. This is a great beer that I plan on having again.

Dark brown beer, thin tan head.  Aroma is quite sweet and malty, very nutty.  Toasty with some light sweetness, some caramel and noticable dried fruits. Flavour is very fruity, plums, cherries, berries, sweet toast and caramel.  Clean malts.  Long fruity finish.  Nice brew.
Rather dark brown colour.  Milk chocolatey malt aroma with caramel accents.  Sweet flavour shows more caramel and chocolate in the malt profile.  Balanced hoppiness.

Coppery rust color. Thin light-tan head. 
Caramelly malt Kool-aid aroma. 
Sweet malts, touch of earth and hops. Some whisky-like aspects too maybe some peaty earty. Maybe some roasty malt thrown in too.
Taste is pretty good, though, tastes like a malty american barleywine that has been aged a year.

Darker than I had expected, but didnt really know what I was getting myself into with this beer.  A bit of chocilate and roast in the smell, minimal head.  Some malts in the taste and a bit of alcohol in the aftertaste, especially if you take largers sips - otherwise very balanced and fairly unnoticeable.  I like the Oatmeal Porter, didnt like the Gaelic, and I am very pleased with this beer, my third Highland.

Habersham Beverage Warehouse, Savannah, Ga. - 22 oz bomber. Dark ruby red appearance, thin but stiocky mocha colored head that leaves thin lacing. Fresh, chocolatey aroma, hints of horehound candy and cinnamon. Full bodied flavor with hints of chocolate, some smoky notes, earthiness and a hint of day old coffee. Mouthfeel is thick enough. Very good - as is most from this brewer.

(Bottle 65 cl) Pours a clear, dark brown with a warm, orangey glow. Lightly creamy, beige head. Full, malty aroma. Rich and full body with loads of roasted malt. Accents of overripe fruit and plums. Dry finish with vague burned notes. Very lovely indeed. 170406

From a 22oz. brown bomber bottle with a short blurb about the ale on the left side of the label, no bottled/freshness date. Made a good appearance, poured an opaque dark chocolate brown with sediment floaties and a small foamy, bubbly pale tannish head that settled into a thin foamy lacing, moderate carbonation overall. Had a big roasted barley and chocolate malty nose with whiffs of hops and alcohol. A crisp, creamy and smooth medium bodied mouth feel, very good drinkability. Delicious sweet-ish roasted barley and chocolate malty taste upfront, a buried fruitiness, followed by a rolling on the tongue Sterling hop bitterness, a subtle peat flavored alcohol warmth in the palate and a sweet chocolate malty finish with a lingering soft hop bitterness. 
A very good Scotch Ale from Highland, the use of malts and hops does a good job of masking the 8% ABV, one of the better Scotch Ales out there, well worth seeking out and trying.

When I saw ale, I was thinking a much lighter drink.  Nope, now I see the chocolate malt added and you can definitely taste those bad boys.  Pours a deep brown with slight red hues.  Nice tan head.  Aromas of roasted barley.  Nice beer from the guys a little north of us.

Bottel - thanks to Fish for the trade.  Hops and butterscotch/caramel aroma.   Opaque brown color with small head.  Flavor a slowly building creamy/smoky chocolate caramel flavor with a mildly bitter hops finish.  Complex, strong and smooth.  An extremely well-made beer.
Dark brown color. Arom aof sweet caramel, mature. Sweet, thick, malty, with a considerable share of caramel. Warming. Nothing special.

A deep red beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is very hoppy combined with strong notes of caramel: The flavor is very sweet, but at the same time extremely dry, with an end that contains light woody notes. A nice powerful Scotch Ale.

Clear red/brown color with an off white head. Aroma is roasty and sweet, whith a hint of smoke. Flavor is earthy and has some fruitiness, plenty of malt sweetness and a small ammount of bitterness on the finish. A good beer, with well hidden alcohol.
Bottle. Dark red brown colour with a beige head. Roasted caramel malty, fruity aroma and taste. Medium to full body with a sweet lighthoppy finish. Nise!
Slightly malty aroma.  Nice clear amber color, with a small head.  The flavor is somewhat of a candied fruit.  The finish is a touch bitter, and the mouthfeel is a little bit sticky.

22oz bottle: Thanks to Argo0 for sharing this one.  Pours to a slightly hazy deep amber with some dark ruby highlights and a medium light tan head.  The aroma is cocoa, light peat, hints of smoke and caramel, and just a touch of alcohol.  The flavor is caramel, apple, fruity alcohol, a bit of sweet peat, mild spice, along with some toffee and light floral hops.  Finishes slightly earthy with some mild hop notes.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2008 (3/2/08, 22oz bottle, thanks wilkie) Medium beige head atop lightly hazed mahogany body, nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, roast, peat, some chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, roast, some smoke, light earthy, cherry.  Creamy medium-full body, quite smooth. (7/4/7/4/14)

(4/2/06, 22oz bottle, thanks wilkie) Crystal clear dark copper body with small beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, some peat, cola.  Taste is moderately sweet, cola, some peat, syrup.  Smooth, light-medium body, some stickiness.   I like it, but would prefer it to be a little less sweet.   (7/3/6/4/13)

(22 oz. bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 target=blank>beeryum, thanks Dave!) Dark cocoa brown with a thick khaki head. Aroma of honey, molasses and caramel. Pretty good lacing. Mouthfeel kind of light, fairly smooth, a little prickly. Seems a bit high on carbonation. Flavor is mostly caramel and toffeeish, with a touch of Scotch. Sweet but only slightly so and this is matched by mild bitterness. Overall flavor is actually pretty restrained. Alcohol pretty well-hidden, only a bit of burn at end. Good beer but nothing that really grabbed me.

Bomber. Poured a dark brown color with a frothy tan head that quickly disappears to a ring. This ring does leave some lacing. The aroma had a fruitiness to it but also some alcohol. First sips had chocolate, caramel and coffee in the flavor. As it warmed the flavor went to dark fruits, wood, and a light alcohol background. Full body and very warming.

Draught at Brixx in Chapel Hill, NC. Clear dark brown color; amber around the edges. Head was foamy and off white. Malty nose with some dried fruit and grassy hops.  Flavor is also complex with caramel, toffee, browned toast, plum, alcohol, and again, the grassy hops. Pretty good beer, especially given my relative lack of fondness for this style.

Again, Book_M_Dano is to thank for this treat.  Mahogany pour with no head.  Sweet wine like notes in the aroma but very light overall.  Very moderate scotch ale.  Cream sherry, sweet malt, a bit fruity (though not anything in particular).  Smooth lightly creamy body.  Very drinkable, I thought.  Though Danos 3 year old grandson did not think so when he managed to get his hands on a sipHa Ha.

A nicely quaffable and moderately smoked scotch. Good balance and smooth. Brown and decent dark head. Chocolate, spice, good carbonation and mouthfeel. Tasty. North Carolina is rising in the charts since they popped their cap

This beer is a deep, dark, opaque, amber-tinged brown color.  It is topped by a four-finger thick, amber-hued tan head that is mostly frothy, but a little creamy in consistency.  The aroma is rich with a mix of fruit and malt; I get notes of fig, rich toffee, hints of salty-chewy malt, concentrated raisins, condensed toasted grain, and a touch of lightly roasted coffee.  The aroma is quite enjoyable; rich and concentrated, which makes for an intriguing nose.

A solid, thick mouthfeel is only partially offset by an ample carbonation that seems a bit out of place in a beer like this.  Luckily a quick swirl and the carbonation is gone; I much prefer more carbonation than less, as I can always get rid of the former.  Ah yes, it is much creamier with less carbonation, and it still has just a touch of prickly carbonation.  This is a malt lovers dream and exactly what I was in the mood for right now.  I get notes of just barely sweet caramel, rich toffee, ample toasted grain, hints of chocolate and something good that I can only describe as a mix of dust from freshly crushed biscuit and melanoid malts.  Underneath all of this malt is something unexpected.  It is hops of course, subtly at first in the background, but here the whole time.  Supporting the huge malt notes, the hops supply a substantial bitterness from start to finish.  They also supply some fruit character, which amplifies the fruit notes from the malt; I get notes of figs and raisins (from the malt), moving to a currant/ berry component that is contributed by the hops.  The hops also bring a touch of spiciness and a hint of herbal character as well.

This beer is definitely hitting the spot; rich, chewy, but not at all cloying, with a surprising depth of hop character, but only if you look for it underneath all that malt character.  There is perhaps a bit of hot alcohol, at times, in the finish, but nothing too detracting.  As the beer warms up, it becomes even maltier and richer; quite nice, yet always with that off-setting bitterness, which, just keeps the malt in check, well makes a valiant attempt to anyway.

Is 31 high enough for Highland Brewing Tasgall Ale?  I dont even know what a cauldron of the gods looks like but it must be used to brew Scotch Ale.  Quite dark but not as heavy as Id had expected a Scotch Ale to be.  Fruity-sweet with a silky palate.  This ones over too soon and were on to.....
Thin white head atop burgandy brown body.  A warm aroma contains notes of butter and wild flower honey.  Sweet tobacco and roast flavours come through.  The tounge is warm, with a menthol feel.

Pour is clear amberish brown with thin almost non existent head...smell is piney hoppy, a little smokey, and some hints of molasses...taste is slightly sweet with a lot of hops...fairly acidic and finish is alcoholic with a strange numbing after cough drop effect...

This bad boy is some fire.  MMMMMMM!! Pours out a deep brown color with lots of malty scent to it.  Flaovr is choco with a wonderful mix of malts.  I love Scotch ales and it is terribly hard to find great scotch ales in NC.  Thanks Highland for this wonderful brew and for the other seven for that matter.

22 oz bottle shared by and with the Master of Disaster, ClarkVV at his humble abode on February 18, 2006.  This one is near-black with just a wisp of head, caramel-reddish hints on the sides of glass....strongly tarry, peaty-woody nose, some sweet chocolate-toffee in the there and dark bread but mostly its pungent and acrid, too overbearing IMHO....big blackstrap molasses character residing in a thick malty foundation in the body, with the smoky/burnt elements nearly as strong as in the nose, though light dried fruitiness helps both to beat back the strong roastiness and add some complexity and sweetness....thick, full body that is never cloying and doesnt really betray its alcoholic heft.  I feel that I should have liked this one more, seems to hit a lot of my favorite elements, but it just didnt quite have the right balance there for me to love it.

Mostly clear, rich brown color with a dark cream head.  Strong caramel and fruits.  Roasty, smokey flavor up front.  Sharp acidity, alcohol effervescing up my nasal passages.  Enjoyable, a bit curious; I thought it would be sweeter.  It was too dry for my taste--I love Scottish ales for their typically over the top malt sweetness.

(Bottle)  Pours a chestnut brown body with a small tan head.  Aroma of cocoa, vinous, dark fruits, and caramel.  Flavor of chocolate and roasted malts, caramel, fruit, and nuts.  Tongue numbing finish...

Bottle. Dusty sweet malt nose. Dark brown body with a patchy film of bubbles. Taste-roasted malts, tobacco, light alcohol that increases as it warms, earthy. Sharp mouthfeel, slight chocolate, subdued peat.

2005 bomber very generously given by Beeryum.  Shared with Muzzlehatch on 2/18/06.Deep auburn-magenta, with swirling tans and melted caramel tints.  Mostly clear, with small, infrequent bubbles creating a moderate amount of light beige head with fair retention, but little to no lacing.  The nose shows silky, milk chocolate sweetness complemented by light bready brown malt notes, a touch of light hazelnuts and even some mild wood smoke.  Dry dark fruits are not so much pungent/tart as they are lightly fruity and mildly acidic.  Aroma strength is quite high as well.  The flavor is steeped in chocolate, with a touch of sweet raisins, rich caramel and brown sugar.  Crusty, dry brown bread and some green, floral and juicy hops add a drying balance.  Some cinnamon and pepper-like ntoes seem out of place for a scotch ale, as its not quite fully clean when I think it should be, but no DMS that I have found in other Highland beers.  Very silky, moistened texture, ending creamy-sweet but with remnants of dry breadiness.  Wonderfully extracted malts, overall, with a moderate carbonation.  No alcohol noted whatsoever.

Ravenous crimson. Finely bubbled dusky-white head. Delightfully aromatic notes of sweet cream, cakey malt, crystallized sugar, and bakers chocolate. Touch of ripe plum esters. Very soft on the palate. Silken layers of malty sweetness greet the palate while beautifully restrained chocolate notes blend softly with lightly roasted nuts and a hint of coffee. Stacks and stacks of everchanging malt flavors. Muted phenols fuse with just enough fluffiness to complement the slight tackiness. Artfully placed powdery malt textures softly dust the palate with a cocoa-laced dryness and enhance the lusher malt elements. Very juicy, as well. Finishes extremely complex, but exquisitely nuanced with coffee and chocolate beneath a dryly chalky, burnt toffee adornment. Not a peaty version, but something this well-structured doesnt have to be. This is simply delicious.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark brown color with a hint of umber at the edges when held to the light. Hearty light tan head. Plenty of malt in the aromas, but a noticeable pine hops. Nose of caramel and light ly roasted malts. Flavors of roasty malts with anise, stewed fruits and caramel. Somewhat heavy and chewy. Long linger of caramel, chocolate and almonds, reminds me of a "Mars" bar. A touch too much in the hops "nose" and pine balance. But a well made malty ale is always good.  Thanks Jonathan.

22oz bottle via trade with jonathan3584 - thanks Jonathan - pours dark bown with a short creamy tan head that stays fairly well and laces a little on the glass on the way down.  Aroma is caramel, chocolate, roasted malts, some smoke and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is caramel, roasted malts, chocolate, and just a touch of butterscotch.  Smooth and creamy palate that coats your mouth and invites you to drink more.  Alcohol is covered well.  A nice brew through and through..

a fine brew i had a few months back at the going away party.  An alomost black brown color to it with a nice nutshell colored head.  very crispy smooth aroma to it, slight smoke and very earthy.  The body was thicker though remaining smooth, solid brew.

Bottle: Courtesy of SpringsLicker, thanks Jay! Pours a small light brown head with good retention and a scattered spotty laceing. Dark brown in color with light brown edging. Nose is light, chocolate and roast with a wee bit of smoke, fairly tame. Nicely creamy palate on a med/light body. Flavors are similar to the aroma profile with the addition of some cocoa and a light nuttiness, smokeyness is still faint. Finish is lightly sweet, notes of caramel and roast, light earthy notes too boot.

A very nice treat, esp. as a new entry on to the NC high gravity scene.  Very well structured, highly (and nice a sexy way) malted, some decent heat, and then the hop bite.  Coats the mouth nicely, a great offering.
One of the best tasting high gravity beers Ive tried.  Warming and smooth.  Aftertaste almost wine-like characteristics.

Since North Carolina popped its cap this year, some the first official high gravity product from the state to make out to Georgia is the Highland Tasgall Ale.  Since Highland has a Scottish theme going on all their labels, the artwork was nearly perfect for the style.  The beer came in a 22 oz. bomber, which I emptied into a Tulip glass.  The body looked almost like molten Hersheys chocolate syrup, due to its dark brown color, and opacity.  The head was rather small at first, and then wend down in a hurry.  The wispy spider web lacing left however was quite good.

The nose was very malty, with an elegant peat accent.  Toffee, chocolate, and coffee aromas filled the nostrils with each breath.  Floral hops were there to brighten things up a little bit.  The taste was just what the aromas had been proclaiming in advance.  Sweet, smoky, and robustly malty, this was undoubtedly Scottish in the flavor profile, but with a little more bitter and citric hop flavor coming through, thanks to being brewed in the Appalachian highlands instead.

I loved the way this beer felt on my tongue.  The body was thick enough to be coating, but not so stout to be chewy.  The velvety smooth swallows had enough of a prickly hop and alcohol bite to them to keep things interesting, but not so much that beer felt dry or astringent.  If there is such a thing as perfect balance in mouthfeel, this one had achieved it.  The aftertaste was more bitter than sweet, which served the purpose of drawing me in to take the next sip.  Drinkability was much better that I was thinking it was going to be.

What a great leap forward for North Carolina!  Welcome, northern neighbors to the wider world of beer.
Dark brown with a thin tan lacing of head. Taste is sweet, somewhat smoky. Malt is prevalent with a faint hop presence. Slight alcohol bite in the finish. Nice way for NC to pop the cap.
Deep red body.  Toasty caramel and a bit fo peat smoke in the aroma.  Big sweet flavor - brown sugar, peat, thick brown malt with some supportive stemmy hops and alcohol.

Bottle-What a way to celebrate the lifing of the 6% cap in NC!  Pours a wonderful black with slight reddish tones.  The head was a froathy, medium light brown to khaki color.  The drink left lacing down the entire length of the glass.  Warm chocolate flavor with sweet fruit flavors throughout.  The extra alchol just tickles the palate.  Wonderful stuff.  ashville wine 4.69

Deep red/mahogany pour with a thick and velvety head.  Some wheaties in the aroma along with slight chocolate covered cherries.  Some sour cherries in the flavor along with roasted chocolate, not too sweet (thankfully) with a whiff of alcohol in the back of the throat.  Very good.  Thanks Blackie.

Milwaukee YEHa!05, one I brought along (thanks for the trade, beeryum!).  Dark chocolate-brown body, thin beige/light tan head.  Toasty, chocolatey aroma, with definite roasted malt character.  Dark fruit appears in the body (cherries, berries?), in addition to heavy toasts, chocolate, and roasted malts.  Just the right touch of sweetness, reminding me in some ways of Bells Double Cream Stout (a favorite).  A very good Scotch Ale, and it is a departure, but a very good one.

Deep, background brown with some safire translucency when put to light.  Tiny, faint tan galaxy formation for the head.  Milk chocolate introduces the tamed nose, with peat, barley bags, Cocoa Puffs cereal and butterscotch serving as its brethren.  Flavor whomp antecedes the otherwise mild aroma.  Chocolate toffee and an evident scotch booze meld together to put on a sweet malt clinic and a prime example of how good a scotch ale can bee.  Spicy peppered brown bread at a fairly formidable degree.  Brown sugar sweetness intermingling with subtle pumpernickel and rye.  Sweet chocolate covered pecans and an admirable, top-shelf single malt scotch, and a finish trailing with a modest twang of spicy butterscotch.  Big thanks to Silphium for sharing!

Dark bown pour and a medium tan head that laces pretty well. Aroma is earthy, slilghtly smoky, and with a touch of bread. Smooth, medium mouthfeel, and a light, tingly carbonation, perhaps a little too much. Roasted barley and spicy hops lead to a surprisingly medium dry finish with a trace of alcohol noted. Very fine. The best from Highland that Ive tasted. Nice to see my home state brewers getting it right.

Thanks Brad!  Pours to a nice toffee and caramel aroma with a nice peat.  The beer pours to a deep brown/black body with a deep tan head.  The flavor is very nicely peaty and smooth.  Peat smoked grains and barley.  The palate is rich and creamy.  Delicious.  The best Scotch Ale that I can remember.

brown w/ some red notes a small tan head ok lace.  Aroma has lactose toffee carmel and roasted barley.  Full smooth creamy palate.  Flavor is a roasted grain/barley and a sweet toffee/carmel malt w/ a lightly hoppy finish.  Pretty darn good.

Bottle:  Courtesy of aracauna via trade.  Great aroma of caramel, toffee, light black licorice, and a hint of piney hops.  Pours a very dark reddish-brown with light transparency when held to the light.  Small off-white head.  Malty up front with chocolate and caramel.  Light black licorice and roasted malt in the middle.  Finishes with a piney hop finish that balances well with all the malt flavors as well as a pretty big alcohol flavor and light warmth.

Bottle: Nearly black, heavy on the dark brown, minor off-white head, fizzy, sparce lacing.   Sweet biscuity malt aroma, a touch of irish moss and even anise.   Very malty start, biscuity, somewhat sweet, touch of licorice and peat.   Very smooth, and clean on the exit.   Tasty!   Big in body, and its smoothness and cleanliness make it one of the beer ones I have had.   Not complex, but solid for the style.   Thanks Larry for sending a couple bottles of this!

Pours a dark deep brown with a lightly-lacing frothy tan head.  Aroma has some mild licorice and mint with some earthy caramel and a touch of piney hops.  Body starts with viscous maltiness and some dry piney hops for balancing the caramel malt.  Finishes sticky and lightly warming with pleasant complexities.  Could use a little more peat, but otherwise quite tasty.

22 oz bottle, via trade w/ CaptainCougar.  Pours a dark mahogany, clear, and with a small off-white head.  Nice sweetly malty nose, some toffee and lightly roasted notes.  Nice Scotch flavor, some peat, coffee, and toffee.  Significant hoppiness mid swallow that leads to a well balanced finish with chocolate notes and alcohol warmth.  Medium bodied with moderate carbonation, leading to a slightly syrupy finish.  Nice take on a Scotch Ale, increased hoppiness noted, but it seems to fit in really well with this beer.  Worth seeking out.
Malty aroma with hint of chocolate. Smooth taste with thick brown head. Nice texture. goes down easy for the alcohol content.

Courtesy of Jonathan3584

Malty aroma with a touch of raisin sweetness. Dark amber/red at the base of the glass and black toward the top. Two finger thick tan head. Raisin in the fore followed by thick chocolate malts and an almost prune like finish. Very thick mouthfeel. This brewery needs more exposure. Some very solid beers.

This is dark brown, almost black, as dark as most Porters. Tall creamy head.
Sweet rich malty raisiny aroma. 
Smooth and creamy , with a flavor profile that follows the malty sweetness found in the aroma.
A nice brew!
Bottle.  Small tan head.  Very dark brown.  Roasty and malty aroma, with very similar flavor.  Quite well balanced, and has a sweet finish with a nice alcohol burn.

Bottle from Whole Foods in Cary.  The pour was hazy dark brown with a splotchy white head.  Aromas of roasty malt, chocoff, some nuts, prunes, and brown sugar hit me, leading to the flavors of roast malt, with some brown sugar, anise, prunes, and some almonds.  Medium palate with a nice complexity.  This one gets bolder and hefty as it warms, and is a nice representation of this style.

Bottle.  Thanks to JIMBOWOOD for this one.  Pours black with ruby undertones in the right light, thick bubbly head..  Aroma is of strong malts and slight alcohol.  Flavor is malty with hop presence, very smooth and spicey.  Very delicate and soft on the palate.

(bonus brew from beeryum)the tasgall had a dark brown body  that shone a bit of deep red in the bottom of the glass.the head reminded me alot of the head from an a&w rootbeer.thick and bubbly and it did leave some nice lacing as it sat.the aroma was also very root beer like with a mix of earth,sweet malts,brown sugar.a mix of chocolate,earth,brown sugar,and root beer made up the aroma.the palate was nice and thick,plus the alcohol was well hidden.this is very interesting in a very good way.

22oz bottle from goldtwins. Pours a flat black color with some light brown head. Nose is light nuts, some decent malt. Taset is very thick, very nice body feel to it, a good velvety. Lots of nuts and malt notes, some light hopps featured.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2005 Bottled version. This is officially the first bottled high gravity beer from North Carolina that Ive had. Mostly clear brown color with a nice thick tan head. Very malty aroma with a healthy amount of caramel. There is a very nice hop presence in this beer that compliments the brown sugar and raisin flavors very nicely. A very enjoyable beer and Im extremely excited that NC brewers finally have the opportunity to make this type of thing.

Draft, Great Decatur Beerfest.  Clear brown.  Caramel molasses sweet malt aroma and some peat to it.  Fairly large caramel malty flavors and some fruity raisin notes.  Alcohol was upfront and peppery.

22 oz bottle, snifter.  Deep and mostly clear brown-garnet-ruby hue with an initially huge, creamy, tan head.  The head is slowly diminishing and leaves behing spots of lacing and a thin sheet of fine bubbles of the beer.  First impression is of strong and sweet malts in the vein of caramel, toffee, and raisins.  Light chocolate, red grapes, peat, and an earthy hop presence as well.  The house aroma of Highland is unmistakeable and perhaps well described as mocha and light dust.  Coffee, walnuts and pure, dark, bready malts are apparent as it warms.  Theres a lot going on in the aroma and its well integrated without being muddled.  Starts with a robust malt sweetness and pleasingly non-existant acidity.  A slight alcohol tinge, but more of the warming rather than bitting variety.  Backend is flush with more malt sweetness and mild noble hop bitterness.  Medium to full bodied, with a creamy texture, and soft carbonation.  Im a fan of scotch ales in general and this is both a good example and not.  Its a really damn tasty interpretation, Im having fun drinking this, but its like a scotch ale meets an alt meets a porter.  Good stuff, good stuff.
dark brown color with some tan head.  some carmel, scotch, alcohol, malty flavors going on.  some butterscotch.  very good.  smooth, but slightly acidic.
A dark brown appearance. A peanut, caramel, and raisin aroma. The flavor is quite malty with some grapes and other dark fruit. Some alcohol does show in the finish. Overall this was a great beer.

Poured a clear dark brown with a small tan head.    Aroma had a few things going on.  Malty, peaty, grape, and a touch of bubble gum.  Sweet malty flavor with some earthy hop and a touch of alcohol pepper on the finish.  Mildly warming.

Sampled at Asheville Brewgrass 2005. Cloudy brown, with nice sturdy head. Nice fruity, toasty aroma. Smooth malt up front, like pumpernickel bread, maybe. Hints of prune and raisin, too, that blend nicely into a surprisingly hoppy finish.

Dark brown body with good carbonation. Good, malty aroma with a touch of alcohol. The flavor is full of caramel and toffee maltiness. The "increased hop level" is still mild compared to the malty rampage, and the bitterness and aroma lent by the hops is just barely more of a contribution than what it provided by the alcohol. Very drinkable given its size.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2005 Draught. Pours mahogany on the edges and a bubbly beige head. The aroma is bittersweet chocolate and raisins. The flavor is complex but superbly blended. Raisin and chocolate are again present, along with smooth caramel sweetness and bitter, almost citric, hops in the finish.  This one definitely ranks among my favorites. If only it were more readily available.

on tap at Barleys in a small goblet.  They were brewing that day at Highlands and the street smelled of boiling beer wort, making me very thirsty.  Tasgall smelled of sweet raisins and munich malt.  The flavor was rich and powerfull, very malty sweet with raisins and a slight prune.  The ABV was certainly pleasant, this may well be described as an Imperial Gaelic Ale.

draught. Pours a rich dark red with a firm tan head. Theres a slight dry fruit aroma, nothing too overwhelming. The flavor is much more powerful with a full rich sweet malt body, some raisins, a slight alochol burn which blends well with the other flavors, and some herbs. Its a tad dry with a rich finish. Odin is certainly pleased with this brew.

"Cauldron of the gods"- I dont know if it stood up to such a name as that, but it was quite the scotch-ale nonetheless.  Living in Asheville, I have been awaiting this beers arrival on the market and have found myself pleased with its glorious high gravity entry into the almighty beer corpus.  Praise the gods!

Another good beer from Asheville!  And beer #5 at the World Beer Fest in Durham, NC.  One of the better beers I tried at the festival that day.  Really dark, coffee, reminded me of some of the sweeter stouts and porters Ive had, but really well balanced.  Not a style that Ive seen a whole lot of.

On tap at Barleys in Asheville.  It had only a little cream-colored head that quickly faded.  I thought that I smelled a little caramel in the aroma, but it wasnt very strong. When I got the dark brown  beer in my mouth though, I was shocked that a beer with that little aroma could pack in so much flavor!  A sweet, very full body with some chocolate notes greeted my tounge and said goodbye with a warming finish that left me wanting another sip.  Good job Highland!  Way to "pop the cap" with flair!

Zero Head. Frothy khaki atollAntique brown body. Decent looking brew. Nose is too faint tyo detect. Roasted barley. Round and fruity. Vinuous and slightly smoked ham. Beer explodes in your mouth. Cocoa and chalk. Whole milk . YEast is especially chalky and smooth. This beer really reminds me of their porter. Maybe a tad less sweet and slightly smokier. Aftertaste is quite similiar. Good beer.
G-rat

On tap.  Has a mild scotch aroma and a dark red appearance that is as close to black as you can get.  Has a powerful choclate type malt with almond undertones.  Finish is smooth and the alcohol is not apparent.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in Charlotte.  Dark, dark brown coloring with a medium off-white head that laced onto the glass very nicely.  Very malty aroma.  Taste was big, rich, very hearty, with a slight warming as it went down.  Highland never ceases to amaze me, and Im glad they are no longer restrained by that stupid 6% law.  Well done!

on draft at barleys taproom in asheville.  pours out dark brown in color with a small brown colored head.  smell is malty, chocolatey, and some subtle hints of alcohol.  taste is smooth, very rich and filling, and roasted tasting.  this is a really good beer from a style that i am not too keen on, but a brewery that is by far my favorite in NC.  i am glad to see that these people were the first to release a high gravity beer in our state which has recently lifted the cap on the % beers can be.  awesome beer guys, cant wait to see what else you guys will come up with.
